chapter.title: User interface guide

section.title: Form
section.para: Form is a user interface building block wich can be represented as a top-level window with a title and a border or can be build-in on a panel or on another form.
A form is a regular JavaScript module with visual components. Any form can be displayed both in desktop client as well in HTML5 web-browser.
Form includes a top-level container, which holds widgets and other containers and accessible under view property.
A widget is a component, which has a visual representation. A container is a component, which holds widgets and other containers.
Each component, as well as the form itself, has a set of properties, which defines the component appearance and behavior, and a set of events (e.g. user actions, for which you can define handlers).

In the desktop client, forms are displayed in separate windows, can be minimized or expanded to the full screen, displayed in other forms as built-in elements (frames) and as internal windows in the DesktopPane component. In the HTML5 browser client, forms are displayed in the same way, but within a browser page.

section.title: New form creation
section.para: To create a new form, perform the following actions:

listitem.para: Select New in the parent directory context menu, or select the parent directory and click New File in the main menu, or click New File on the main toolbar, or use a corresponding keyboard shortcut.
Select Form type of the Platypus application element in the context menu, or select Choose file type Platypus application elements on the wizard first step and click Next.
Enter the name for the new application element in the Name field and click Finish to create it, or click Cancel to cancel.

section.title: Visual UI editor
section.para: Edit form components layout using the visual form editor. To open the editor double-click the application element in the project tree.
To edit the form:

listitem.para: Open the Design tab of the module editor.
Drag a widget, a container or a menu from the components palette onto the form.
Arrange the components on the form.
Set the general properties of the form and properties of each component on the Properties panel, e.g. text font, foreground and background colors.
Specify handlers functions of the form and components on the Properties/Events, write the event handlers code in the JavaScript editor.
Configure the form's data model and write code responsible for data manipulations.
Save the form by clicking Save All on the Platypus Application Designer tool bar or by pressing Ctrl S shortcut.

note.para: A form should contain JavaScript code, responsible for user interface. Business logic should be implemented in server modules.

section.para: Form's structure is presented as a tree in the form inspector panel. Use the inspector to select a widget, a container or a menu, to move a component from one container to another, and to select the container layout.
Drag components up or down in the inspector tree or activate the Move Up, Move Down, and Change Order context menu items to set the order along the Z axis.

To run a quick preview of the form, click Preview design on the visual editor tool bar. The preview window opens, showing a visual representation of the form, which is identical to its look in runtime.

The anchors layout is enabled for all form's containers by default. To choose some other layout for the specific container, select the layout menu item in the Set Layout submenu from the container's context menu in the inspector component tree.
Add a component from the pallete using the visual editor, anchors are attached for the nearest container's sides and width and height values are automatically set.

Change dimensions of the component and its location by using the mouse or arrows keys. When you move a component using arrows keys, the position of the component is tied to the grid. Hold down the Ctrl to move the component smoothly. Hold down the Shift key to expand the widget.

note.para: To define form's editor settings, use the properties setting dialog: Tools Options Miscellaneous GUI Builder .

section.para: To enable or disable an anchor, use anchors buttons on the form editor toolbar.

As an alternative way to specify the layout anchors, use widget node menu in the inspector: enable the corresponding anchor in the Anchor submenu. Thus, if there's one anchor enabled for one coordinate, then this anchor and the appropriate dimension will be used. If there are two anchors enabled, then they will be used, and the dimension will be extended.
Specify values for anchors and dimensions explicitly, changing the values of the component's properties panel in the Layout properties group: Left, Top, Right, Bottom, Left, Width, and Height.

Anchors properties values are specified as a strings together with the indication of measurement units: pixels or percentages. If measurement units are not specified, pixels are used. If a value is defined as a percentage, this anchor and dimension will be changed while maintaining the defined value when changing dimensions of the container, for example : 60px, 30%, 40.

Use the component alignment control buttons on the form editor tool bar to align widgets in relation to each other. Alignment buttons become active when you select multiple widgets. To select multiple widgets, click them while holding down the Ctrl key.
Specify a component's the properties and event handlers:

listitem.para: Click a form area, which is free from other components, or select a form node in the component inspector.
Change properties of the form on the Properties panel.
Specify the event handlers on the Properties/Events panel.
Write code of the handlers in the JavaScript editor.

To remove an event handler, delete the name of the handler from the corresponding event field; as a result, the <none> name is assigned to the handler and the handler function will be removed from the code.

section.title: Introduction to model widgets
section.para: Model widgets are components, which can interact with the data model and respond to the model's datasets events.

You can bind a model widgets to any data model entity dataset (including "parameters" entity). This dataset will change in response to the user actions on the widgets and its changes will lead to automatic update of data displayed on all bound widgets.

Some model widgets represents a single dataset object and its specific field. This data object is the object at the cursor position. Other more complex model widgets can represent multiply objects in dataset and control the cursor in this dataset.
Model widgets has the same basic properties and event as standard widgets. It is not recommended to specify handlers of low-level events (keyboard, mouse movement events, etc.) for model widgets.
Configure specific properties for binding to data model, using properties in the Model binding category.
Any model widget can be presented as an independent component and as a ModelGrid widget cell. There is an "abstract" cell in each model widget. It is available in the onRender event handlers.
For such a cell, the following properties are defined:

listitem.para: display is the displayed text
style is the style of displaying

section.title: ModelGrid
section.para: ModelGrid model widget is a powerful widget intended to display and enter data, which is presented in a tabular form and as a tree. ModelGrid widget is the most powerful UI component.
The component has the following features:

listitem.para: Tree grid view of data.
Frozen "non-scrollable" rows and/or columns areas.
Multilevel header. To use this feature, one have to define nested columns structure.
Entity's data array scrolling (cursor reposition).
Data editing.
Dynamic columns with another dataset as a columns source.
Fixed, resiable and draggable columns.

section.para: Fixed columns are the columns, which are intended for displaying the specific fields of the dataset in the fixed position on the grid. You can also configure any number of veer columns, each of which may include dynamic child columns.
To configure the widget properties:

listitem.para: Select the model entity for the component. To do this, use the entity property. Datasource binding will be created. To delete the binding, click the clear button.

If necessary, freeze the required number of columns on the left and/or rows on the top of the grid ‚Äî these columns and rows won't be scrolled with other columns and rows. To do this, set the number of fixed columns using the fixedColumns and fixedRows properties.

Choose the appearance of the service column ‚Äî a service column appears to the left of other columns and is used to display the cursor icon and select rows; select one of the following options: None ‚Äî the service column is not displayed, Usual ‚Äî a normal view with the cursor icon, Check box ‚Äî a cursor icon and widget, which allows you to select multiple rows, Radio button ‚Äî a cursor icon and widget, which allows you to select only one row of the grid.
Define the onRender event handler, which will be called for the data grid cells, if a similar handler was not defined for their columns.

section.para: To add, remove and configure grid columns:

listitem.para: Use the form inspector ‚Äî the inspector displays the structure of the data grid columns and allows you to edit it; columns can be embedded into each other.
Enter the column title using the title property.
Move the selected columns up and down using the Move up and Move down context menu items.
To add columns corresponding to the fields of the linked data model entity, select Fill columns ‚Äî in this case, link to the entity fields will be performed automatically.

section.para: To configure the column properties:

listitem.para: Select a column in the form inspector.
Specify an identifier for the column using the name property, by this identifier this column can be accessed from JavaScript code.
Set the column title font using the font property.

Set the width of the column using the width property. The column width is specified in pixels. If the width of the grid is smaller than (in this case scroll bars appear) or equal to the sum of all columns width, such width will be actual column's width. If the grid width exceeds this value, the width of each column is proportionally increased.
Set the "read only" mode for the column by checking the readOnly property.
Enable or disable the visual representation of the column by checking the visible property.

Define a handler of the selection event for the onSelect column cells using the Events tab on the properties panel; the select button appears in cells only if the handler is defined; if necessary, define a special value selection procedure in the handler: for example, open a special value selection dialog, etc.
Define the onRender event handler using the Events tab on the properties panel.
Enable or disable the operation mode for the column ‚Äî standard or dynamically expanded ‚Äî by checking the veer property.

section.para: To configure the column in standard mode:

listitem.para: Specify the entity field, to which the column should be linked. To do this, use the field property.

Define a widget, which will be used for displaying in the column cells. Select its type from the View context menu. The choices will be compatible with the type of the linked entity field. Set properties of the corresponding widget (see the corresponding sections for the description of the model widget setting procedure).

section.para: In the expanded mode, a column can contain an arbitrary number of child columns. Their combination can be changed dynamically during the application execution. The combination of the child columns is determined by a special (column) entity in the data model. Values for the child column cells are determined by another (cell) entity, the objects of which also contain references to objects in the main entity (grid's rows source) and to the column entity objects.
To configure the column in expanded mode:

listitem.para: Check the veer property.
Define an entity, which contains a list of columns (a Propertiesentity on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the columnsEntity property.
Define an entity field, which contains names of dynamic columns (a Properties.Name field on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the columnsDisplayField property.
Define an entity, which contains cell values (a Values entity on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the cellsEntity property.
Define an entity field, which contains references to the main entity (a Values.MainID field on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the rowsKeyField property.
Define an entity field, which contains references to the column list entity (a Values.PropID field on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the columnsKeyField property.
Define an entity field, which contains cell values (a Values.Value field on the example figure); to do this, set a value for the cellValueField property.

Define a widget to be used as a representation of cells; to do this, select its type in the context menu of the form inspector column: the choices will be compatible with the type of the linked entity field; set properties of the corresponding widget (see the corresponding sections for the description of the Model Controls setting procedure).
Check the substitute property to hide the parent column; in this case, dynamic columns will be displayed the same way as fixed columns of the parent level.

section.para: The widget can be configured to display a tree structure in the first column on the left ‚Äî elements of the tree visual representation (expand/collapse icons for nodes) are added to this column. Other columns are displayed as usual.
For the tree structure to work, we need an entity, which contains a field referring to the instances of the same entity, thus forming a hierarchical data structure.
A tree structure in the grid can function in two modes:

listitem.para: A simple mode, in which all tree levels are loaded by a single query.
A "lazy" mode, in which each level is loaded as the nodes are expanded.

note.para: The simple tree operation mode is acceptable only for small sets of data, since in this mode all tree elements are requested simultaneously and it can lead to problems with the performance and responsiveness of the user interface. For large data sets, use the "lazy" tree operation mode.

section.para: To configure a tree in the simple mode:

listitem.para: Select a column on the left panel; activate the Tree tab.
Select the All levels from single query item.

Define a data set linking field; to do this, click the select button next to the Select unary link field for tree building field; in the form, that opens, select a data set field, which is responsible for hierarchical relationships; in order to remove the selection, click the clear button.

important.para: The linking field should be in the same data set, which is configured as the grid rows source.

section.para: To arrange a lazy tree, you should create an entity based on a query, which returns child elements by the parent record identifier passed as a parameter, for example:
section.programlisting: /** * @name LazyTree */ SELECT * FROM tree_table t WHERE t.PARENT_ID = :parentId OR (:parentId IS NULL AND t.PARENT_ID IS NULL)
section.para: To configure a "lazy" tree:

listitem.para: Select a column on the left panel; activate the Tree tab.
Select the Deeper level with new query item.

Define the parent record identifier parameter for the data set; to do this, select a parameter from the drop-down list to the left of the = symbol. To remove the parameter selection, click the clear button.

Define the records identifier field: to do this, click the select button to the right of the = symbol; in the form, that opens, select a data set field ‚Äî the record identifier. To remove the identifier field selection, click the clear button.

section.title: ModelImage
section.para: ModelImage widget displays an image. The state of this component is linked to a field of the data model, which contains binary data of the image in one of the following formats: GIF, JPEG, PNG.

note.para: This field usually corresponds to the BLOB type in the database.
In the current Platypus Platform version, this component is supported only in the J2SE client.

section.para: To configure the widget:

listitem.para: Set the entity property for the component, using the field property on the properties panel; select the data model parameter or data model entity property in the dialog.
Set the plain property to prevent image scaling.

section.para: To upload an image or other binary file into the database, open the file selection dialog in the component selection event handler. In the handler, assign a file byte array to the value property of the ModelImage control. Then the contents of the file be added to the control and the corresponding entity field will be changed. If you later request saving of the model.save() model, the file contents will by saved by the model in usual way.

section.title: ModelMap
section.para: A widget is used to display a map and objects on it; it displays the map mount by loading bitmap tiles from the network using a given URL. An arbitrary number of layers are imposed upon the map to display objects.
The map component allows you to position the map, change its scale, turn layers on and off, select objects, etc.

note.para: In the current Platypus Platform version, this widget is supported only in the J2SE client.

section.para: Coordinates and shapes of the displayed objects should be presented using the "Geometry" data type. The layer entity should contain one column of the "Geometry" type and an arbitrary number of columns containing additional attributes.

Each layer should have an assigned entity, which contains information about objects. One entity can be linked with one or more layers. If the entity is linked with several layers, a field with information about entity instance belonging to the layer should be defined. In this case, each layer should have its own identifier for this field. A layer identifier must be a positive integer.
A map has the following specific properties:
To configure the map:

listitem.para: Specify the map title by filling out the Title field.

Link the data model parameter to the map scale: to do this, click the select button next to the Zoom factor parameter field, on the form for selecting a data model field choose the data model parameter; to remove the parameter link, click the clear button.

Provide a description of the coordinate system used by the map in the well known text format (WKT). To do this, fill out the Geographic CRS WKT field. This text should also contain projected CRS definition.
Specify the map event handler by filling out the Map event listener field ‚Äî an event handler will be created.

section.para: The backingURL and Geographic CRS WKT values are specific for map tiles providers, such as Open Street Map:

listitem.para: An example of value for backingURL:http://%s.tile.openstreetmap.org/%d/%d/%d.png
